content: The Act titled "Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity, and Training Act of 2002" references Title 38, United States Code. Title I focuses on Employment Services and includes definitions. The Act "Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity, and Training Act of 2002" defines terms such as "veteran" and "eligible person" in reference to Title 38, United States Code. The term "veteran" aligns with the definition in section 4211(4) of Title 38, while an "eligible person" includes the spouse of a service-connected disability deceased person or an active duty Armed Forces member listed as missing in action or captured by a hostile entity for over ninety days. The term "State" in the Act refers to the various states of the United States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico, with the possibility of including other territories as determined necessary by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The term "servicemember" refers to an individual in the Armed Forces being separated within specified time periods. Establishment of a national performance-based job-search assistance program to help veterans, servicemembers, and eligible individuals find employment and reduce unemployment duration. The program will also aid employers in hiring qualified individuals. The Department of Veterans Affairs will utilize web-based technology to improve services for veterans globally. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish the "Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity and Training Program" (VEBOT) to provide employment services to veterans, servicemembers, and eligible individuals. State Governors or other entities will receive grants to assist in obtaining optimal employment opportunities. Regulations will be prescribed to implement the VEBOT program. The regulations for the Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity and Training Program (VEBOT) will address eligibility criteria, types of services, service delivery methods, monitoring of service providers, and cooperation with State employment agencies to ensure veterans have access to workforce services. The Department of Veterans Affairs will coordinate with the Department of Labor to ensure veterans receive priority in employment services through State and local one-stop delivery systems. The entity within the Department of Veterans Affairs administering the program will be determined. Regulations will consider task force recommendations and consult with the Secretary of Defense on eligibility criteria for servicemembers. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish a task force to make recommendations on eligibility criteria for servicemembers. The task force will include representatives from veterans service organizations, employers, and State Governors. The Secretary of Labor, Secretary of Defense, and Secretary of Transportation will also be members. The VEBOT program services will be provided competitively with performance requirements. The VEBOT program ensures services are provided competitively with performance requirements. Governors must meet agreed performance requirements or request adjustments. Failure to meet requirements may result in intervention by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may provide assistance to grantees, including training, technical assistance, and staff development. If a grantee continues to underperform, the Secretary may remove funds and seek a new service provider through a competition. Wage record information can be used for program performance measurement. The Secretary of Labor assists the Secretary of Veterans Affairs in accessing wage information. State Governors and entities receiving funds must comply with cost principles and regulations set by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Proper fiscal controls and accounting procedures are required for the disbursal of Federal funds. Each grantee must maintain appropriate records in accordance with accounting principles. Grantees must comply with uniform administrative requirements for grants and contracts. If a service provider is not in compliance, corrective action must be taken by the grantee. The Secretary may remove funds if corrective action is not taken. The Secretary may remove funds from the grantee and solicit a new grantee through competition. Up to 15 percent of funds can be used for administration costs. The Secretary can reserve up to 25 percent of funding for pilot projects and demonstration programs related to the VEBOT program. The Secretary can reserve up to 25 percent of funding for pilot projects and demonstration programs to establish the effectiveness of proposed innovative program designs and service delivery systems. TRANSFER OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR ADMINISTRATION OF CERTAIN EMPLOYMENT SERVICES TO SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. During the specified period, responsibilities under certain sections of title 38, United States Code, will be transferred from the Secretary of Labor to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, including the function of the Assistant Secretary of Labor for Veterans' Employment and Training. Personnel necessary to carry out these responsibilities will also be transferred to the Department of Veterans Affairs. During a specified period, functions related to employment services for disabled veterans will be transferred from the Secretary of Labor to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Coordination between the two departments will facilitate this transfer. SEC. 105. REPEAL OR AMENDMENT OF EXISTING AUTHORITIES. Repeal of various sections and amendments to Chapter 43 provision and Advisory Committee related to the Department of Veterans Affairs. Amendments to replace references to "Labor" with "Secretary of Veterans Affairs" and vice versa in various subsections related to Veterans Employment, Business Opportunity, and Training Program. TRANSFER OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR ADMINISTRATION OF TRANSITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM TO THE SECRETARY OF VETERANS AFFAIRS. The text chunk states that references to the Secretary of Labor and Secretary of Veterans Affairs in section 1144 of title 10, United States Code, are interchangeable. Additionally, it mentions an amendment to section 1144(d) regarding the use of personnel for grant recipients under the Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity, and Training Act of 2002. The text chunk allows the Secretary to determine appropriate use of personnel for grant recipients under the Veterans' Employment, Business Opportunity, and Training Act of 2002, without significant interference with services to eligible veterans and other recipients. The responsibility for administering homeless veterans' reintegration programs is transferred to the Secretary of Veterans Affairs from the Secretary of Labor. The effective date for the provisions of this Act is October 1, 2002.
